title: Dr
name: Andrew Cox
research_interest_terms: Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Social data science
research_interest_summary: My main interests are in the responsible implementation of AI systems in the context of libraries (e.g. university and national libraries, health libraries or the corporate or government context) and their impact on the information profession. So I am interested in the strategic decision making around AI, the relevant applications, ethics issues, the competencies required by professionals to support them and the implementation drivers and challenges.

title: Professor
name: Ashutosh Tiwari
affiliation: Faculty Director of Research and Innovation - Engineering, University of Sheffield
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Human computer interface, Machine learning, Optimisation, Robotics
short_biography: Professor Ashutosh Tiwari (PhD CEng FIMechE FIET) holds the prestigious RAEng/Airbus Research Chair in Digital Manufacturing at the University of Sheffield. He is also the Faculty Director of Research and Innovation for Engineering at the University of Sheffield. Internationally renowned for research in digital manufacturing, he has a track record of leading cross-TRL projects worth over £15mn, produced 343 publications (155 journal and 133 conference papers, h-index 38, citation count over 9,000), graduated 36 PhDs, and was awarded an EPSRC HVM Catapult Fellowship. He is an Associate Editor of ‘AI for Engineering Design, Analysis and Manufacturing Journal’ (Cambridge University Press).
research_interest_summary: AI for Manufacturing

title: Dr
name: Cass Zhixue Zhao
research_areas: Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Natural language processing

title: Professor
name: Dennis Wang
position: Advanced Visiting Fellow, University of Sheffield
affiliation: Imperial College London and A*STAR Bioinformatics Institute
research_interest_terms: Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Privacy and trust, Visualisation
short_biography:
Prof Dennis Wang holds the Academy of Medical Sciences Professorship (Chair in Data Science) at Imperial College London, and is a Visiting Fellow at the University of Sheffield. Additionally, he is a principal investigator with both A*STAR’s Singapore Institute for Clinical 
 Sciences and the Bioinformatics Institute. He received his PhD in Biostatistics from the University of Cambridge, followed by postdoctoral research at AstraZeneca and Microsoft Research in the area of computational biology.
research_interest_summary: Dennis’ research focuses on translating patterns in the human genome into actionable information that accelerates the development of treatments for complex diseases. Specialising in big data analysis, drug development (small molecules and biologics), algorithmic development, software design, web service development, genomic profiling, and statistical inference. His experience includes applying machine learning and statistical approaches to identify patterns from large genomic data sets and providing clinically actionable biomarkers to drug development teams.

title: Mr
name: Edwin Brown
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography:
Edwin joined the Research Software Engineer (RSE) team in October 2022. He comes from a background in geophysics following a BSc and MSc in Geophysical Sciences at the University of Leeds. After university, he worked in the private sector, developing machine learning (ML) workflows to solve geophysical imaging and inversion problems.

Edwin has practical experience in the designing, training and evaluation of ML models. He is experienced in Python having worked with data science libraries such as Numpy, Pandas, Scikit-learn, Tensorflow and Keras. He has a growing interest in MLOps (Machine Learning Operations) and the practical challenges of scaling up ML practices.
research_interest_summary: Edwin's role as a Research Software Engineer (RSE) is to aid researchers in Machine Learning Projects. This can be as simple as bug fixing a training script to more complex challenges such as developing software for an end-to-end machine learning project. He also helps deliver Git and Deep Learning training.

title: Dr
name: Gavin Boyce
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Visualisation
short_biography: I have a background in Philosophy, Computing and Psychology. I currently work as Head of Faculty & Research Partnership in the University of Sheffield library. Day-to-day I head up the small, but perfectly formed, Faculty Engagement team; 12 dedicated specialist librarians who endeavour to support both staff and student needs across all disciplines within the University. Much of my focus is on ensuring that the Library will continue to be the beating heart of the University in five to ten years time and in the current environment this requires a combination of careful long-term planning and fleet-footed opportunism.
research_interest_summary: My PhD thesis was on the topic of Artificial Intelligence, an an interdisciplinary piece of work that had neither the a priori rigour that it takes to satisfy pure philosophers, nor sufficient lines of code to mollify decent computer scientists. I spent my nights working on Yorick Wilkes' Japanese-Electronic dictionary. I have leaned towards AI, HCI and the applications thereof ever since.

title: Dr
name: Giuliano Punzo
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Mathematical modelling, Multi-agent reasoning
short_biography: Dr Punzo received the BEng and the MEng in aerospace engineer from the University of Naples Federico II and forked for a brief period at Thales Alenia Space (Turin). He started the doctoral studies and was awarded a PhD in Swarm Engineering in 2014 at the University of Strathclyde in Glasgow. Giuliano held research and teaching posts at the University of Strathclyde, the University of Glasgow and The University of Sheffield before becoming a lecturer in Aerospace Systems at the department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering at the University of Sheffield in 2019.
research_interest_summary: Giuliano’s research interests are in the broad area of control theory and complex systems. His current research aims at understanding complex dynamics at the interface between social and technical systems. These include the use of public services such as transportation or water systems, how these impact the demographic and the resilience of both the infrastructure and the community they serve. Research areas of interest include network theory, control theory, games on networks, consensus, and complexity.

title: Dr
name: Grant Hill
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Optimisation, Visualisation
short_biography: I obtained my MChem degree from the University of York in 2002, followed by a PhD in theoretical chemistry from the same institute in 2005. After periods of postdoctoral study in Cardiff and Washington State, I had a temporary position at the University of Glasgow. I joined the University of Sheffield in 2014.
research_interest_summary: I am interested in exploring fundamental questions in chemistry/physics at the molecular level using theoretical and computational tools. Recent areas of focus include the use of data science and machine learning techniques to design new molecules/materials and to improve the methods of quantum chemistry.

title: Dr
name: Grigorios Kyritsakas
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Optimisation, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: Dr Grigorios Kyritsakas received his MEng in Environmental Engineering from the Technical University of Crete and his Msc in hydrology from Imperial College London. He then worked as a water engineering consultant for a period of 10 years working on the design of water and wastewater treatment plants and distribution systems. He then got back in academia in 2017 to purchase a PhD in data analytics for drinking water quality at University of Sheffield Civil and Structural engineering department. With the completion of his studies in 2021, he stayed in the department as a post-doc research associate working on machine learning application for improving drinking water quality.
research_interest_summary: Grigorio's research interests are in the are of water quality, hydraulics, water infrastructures, and public health. His current research focuses on application of machine learning applications for understanding factors related to water quality deterioration, predicting future deterioration events and improving the quality of the water that is consumed. His research area of interest also includes the digital transformation of the water systems and the application of graph network theory in drinking water distribution systems.

title: Professor
name: Haiping Lu
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Science, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Multi-agent reasoning, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: I am a Professor of Machine Learning, the Turing Network Development Award Lead, and Insigneo Research Director for Healthcare Data / AI at University of Sheffield. I am is also the lead organiser of the Alan Turing Institute’s interest group on meta-learning for multimodal data and the Machine Learning Theme Lead for Sheffield in the N8 Centre of Excellence in Computationally Intensive Research. I serve as an Associate Editor of IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, and IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems. I was a recipient of an Amazon Research Award, an AAAI Outstanding PC Member Award, and an IEEE CIS Outstanding PhD Dissertation Award. I am a Senior Member of IEEE.
research_interest_summary: My research focuses on developing translational AI technologies for better analysing multimodal data in healthcare and beyond, particularly multidimensional data and heterogeneous graphs in bioinformatics and medical imaging. I lead the development of the PyKale library (https://github.com/pykale/pykale) to provide more accessible machine learning from multiple sources for interdisciplinary research, officially part of the PyTorch ecosystem (https://pytorch.org/ecosystem/).

title: Dr
name: Jacob Macdonald
position: Lecturer in GIS and Spatial Analysis
affiliation: Department of Urban Studies and Planning
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: Jacob Macdonald is Lecturer in GIS and Spatial Analysis with the Dept. of Urban Studies and Planning. He completed his PhD in Economics and Finance at the Nova School of Business and Economics, and then worked as a Geographic Data Scientist with the University of Liverpool and the Geographic Data Science Lab/ Consumer Data Research Centre. His teaching and research combines applied data science, urban and environmental spatial analysis for policy and planning.
research_interest_summary: My work makes use of the increasingly available big, spatial and open datasets for research in city sciences and planning. I have a broad interest in the economic and environmental spatial processes at play in the urban context, and how they influence our observed behaviour. My work has a common theme of using data and statistical methods to explore how individuals measure, value and interact with their local built and natural environments.

title: Dr
name: Joe Atkinson
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Security and Business and Public Policy
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics
research_interest_summary: Law and Regulation of AI

title: Dr
name: Kathryn Simpson
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Information theory, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Visualisation
short_biography:
I am a Lecturer in Digital Humanities in the Digital Humanities Institute (DHI), with a particular research focus on critical digital cultural heritage.
    I was previously a Lecturer in Information Studies at the University of Glasgow and prior to that a Fellow of the Institute for Advanced Studies in the Humanities at the University of Edinburgh.
    I am a Trustee of the David Livingstone Birthplace, Chair of both the Expert Advisory Panel and of the Audience, Learning, Engagement and Collections Committee. I am an Associate Project Scholar and UK Outreach Coordinator of Livingstone Online.
research_interest_summary: I am interested in digital tools and platforms which support open-access historical research and enable cross-silo scrapping of texts, images and objects to allow us to renegotiate histories in ways which do not belittle or obfuscate traditional knowledges and frameworks whilst providing richer and deeper understanding of heritage. I am particularly interested in the application of AI in cultural heritage environments and its use in negating or challenging established patterns and behaviours around museal collections.

title: Mr
name: Lawrence Schobs
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: I am a third year PhD student researching medical image analysis with deep learning. I focus on landmark localization and estimating uncertainty.
research_interest_summary: computer vision, medical image analysis, landmark localization, segmentation, uncertainty estimation

title: Professor
name: Lyudmila Mihaylova
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer vision, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Multi-agent reasoning, Robotics, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: I am a Professor in Signal Processing and Control at the Automatic Control and Systems Engineering Department, on Sheffield Robotics and Insigneo. I serve as Associate Editor-in-Chief for the IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems, a Senior Area Editor of the Signal Processing journal and as part of the organising committees of IEEE conferences on information fusion, ICASSP, conferences on intelligent transport and others.
research_interest_summary: I have broad research interests and expertise in the areas of autonomous systems with applications to cities, autonomous and assisted living systems. My recent work is in the areas of machine learning, intelligent sensing, navigation, tracking and other tasks with multi-sensor data – from images and videos to time series data. Autonomous image and video analytics faces a number of challenges due to the huge volumes of data that sensors provide, the changeable environmental conditions and other factors. However, it is important to know when the methods work well and when they are not reliable, e.g. how much could we trust the obtained results? How could we quantify the impact of uncertainties on the developed solutions?

title: Dr
name: Mark Hodgkinson
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Parallel computing
short_biography: I have extensive experience analysing large datasets and writing data processing algorithms for High Energy Physics Experiments. I did my Phd with the University of Manchester, spending most of the time on placement at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Laboratory working on the BaBar experiment.  I then joined the University of Sheffield as an e-science software developer for several years working on data processing software for the ATLAS experiment at CERN. I was subsequently a Research Associate working on the ATLAS experiment with Sheffield before being promoted to Research Fellow.
research_interest_summary: As the main developer of the Particle Flow data processing algorithm, used by the ATLAS experiment to process data centrally for physicists to subsequently analyse, I am particularly interested in how we could augment or replace this with a machine learning approach. Currently I am interested in studying Convolutional Neural Networks, Graph Neural Networks and Mixed Density Networks to provide predictions of charge particle energy deposits in the ATLAS particle detectors. I have in the past worked on usage of machine learning techniques to identify particle types on High Energy Physics Experiments, some of which are currently deployed as standard techniques used in the ATLAS data processing workflows.

title: Dr
name: Mark Stevenson
position: Senior Lecturer in Natural Language Processing
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Information theory, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Optimisation, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Visualisation
short_biography: I am a Senior Lecturer in Computer Science and member of the Natural Language Processing group. I have been Principal Investigator of projects funded by a range of sources including the EPSRC, EU and Google. I have been an EPSRC Advanced Research Fellow and previously co-ordinated an EU-funded project. Before taking up my current role I worked in a range of commercial and academic organisations including Reuters Ltd (where I was involved in the production and dissemination of the widely used Reuters Corpus), Adastral Park (British Telecom’s research lab) and the Center for the Study of Language and Information, Stanford University.
research_interest_summary: My research focuses on Natural Language Processing and Information Retrieval. My main interest is in the development of systems that allow users to access information contained within large collections of documents and to make decisions based on this information. To this end I have worked on a range of topics including lexical semantics, scholarly document processing, Information Extraction, plagiarism/reuse detection, Technology Assisted Review, exploratory search and evidence synthesis. I have applied these technologies to a range of areas including biomedical text mining, cultural heritage and software testing.

title: Mr
name: Max Gamill
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: I am a PhD student in the Materials Science and Engineering department at the University of Sheffield working within the Pyne lab, led by Dr Alice Pyne. I graduated from the University of Leeds, obtaining a First Class master’s degree in Physics, where I implemented and analysed the quality of deep learning 3D super-resolution models under the supervision of Dr Aleks Ponjavic. Here, I also completed a year in industry with IBM as a technical support analyst for the business reporting tool Cognos Analytics.
research_interest_summary:
The flexibility of DNA allows it to adopt a wide range of conformations induced by its compaction within the nucleus, and interactions with DNA-processing enzymes during vital cell processes such as transcription and replication. This variation in topological complexity has been shown to influence DNA-protein interactions such as those with Topoisomerases, antibacterial and anti-cancer therapeutics and CRISPR-Cas-9.

My research investigates DNA topological complexity seen in atomic force microscopy (AFM) images, and aims to quantify features and characteristics seen within datasets via machine learning techniques in an open and accessible way through our AFM image processing software, TopoStats (https://github.com/AFM-SPM/TopoStats.git).

title: Dr
name: Michael Farnsworth
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer vision, Human computer interface, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Optimisation, Robotics
short_biography: Dr Farnsworth graduated from the biological sciences having pursued a BSc in Biochemistry at Cardiff University before undertaking an MSc in Computer Science at the University of the West of England. He continued with his interest in biologically inspired computation, undertaking a PhD at Cranfield University on the evolutionary design optimisation of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS). He continued with this theme over a number of projects throughout his time at Cranfield University and the University of Sheffield, ranging from autonomous maintenance, manufacturing informatics and process optimisation. He is currently the lead researcher for the digital manufacturing theme within the EPSRC Future Electrical Machines Manufacturing hub.
research_interest_summary: In my current role as a research associate within ACSE and research lead within the FEMM hub I focus on developing digital and sensor-based solutions for automation and tracking and traceability of manufacturing processes. The core of this research is centred on my interests in biologically inspired computing, whether it be evolutionary computation, machine learning and AI, or robotics and cognitive neuroscience. This includes investigating the latest deep neural network-based machine vision and machine learning solutions, whilst exploring novel bio-inspired event based sensors and cognitive architectures. In my free time I also explore how machine learning can be incorporated into the field of climate science and modelling.

title: Mr
name: Mohammod Naimul Islam Suvon
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning, Natural language processing
short_biography: Mohammod Suvon completed his bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Engineering from North South University, Dhaka, Bangladesh. He has recently completed his Master's in Computer Science with speech and language processing at the University of Sheffield, UK. Currently, he is working as a research support engineer under Dr. Haiping Lu.
research_interest_summary: Mohammod Suvon's current research interest is in multimodal learning on clinical datasets.

title: Dr
name: Monica Lestari Paramita
research_areas: Data-centric Engineering, Humanities and Social Sciences
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Natural language processing, Social data science
short_biography: I am a Lecturer in Data Science and the deputy head of the Information Retrieval Research Group in the Information School, University of Sheffield. I obtained my PhD from the Information School, University of Sheffield in 2019. Prior to my lectureship, I worked as a researcher for 10 years in diverse areas of Information Retrieval and Natural Language Processing. My research roles included investigating cross-lingual similarity in the Web, developing systems to support information access, and analysing users' behaviour when interacting with such systems. I have co-authored over 25 publications, ranging from conference papers, book chapters, and journal articles.
research_interest_summary: My research focuses on the study of bias and transparency in information retrieval and multilingual information access. I am especially interested to investigate how bias-aware search engines should be designed to support users in their search tasks. I am also interested in researching cross-lingual similarity in Wikipedia; this includes creating methods to measure cross-lingual similarity, understanding the extent of dissimilarity in Wikipedia and why they exist, and how this impacts different users (e.g., users in different locations or those speaking different languages).

title: Dr
name: Olayiwola Oladiran
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Robotics, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: Ola is currently a Lecturer in Real Estate at the Urban Studies and Planning Department. He gained his PhD in Real Estate and Urban Economics from Henley Business School, University of Reading. He previously worked as a Lecturer in Real Estate at Leeds Beckett University and Henley Business School, University of Reading. His research focuses on real estate economics with a core interest in digital/IT applications to real estate (PropTech), residential real estate, and operational real estate markets.
research_interest_summary: My broad research interest is in real estate economics. I am currently exploring the various ways through which digital technology can enhance the efficiency of real estate operations and practice, and how these can further improve various aspects of the built environment. I also utilise various quantitative techniques to understand the demand and pricing mechanism in operational and residential real estate markets.

title: Mr
name: Peizhen Bai
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Information theory, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Parallel computing
short_biography: I am a CS Ph.D. student at the University of Sheffield, supervised by Dr. Haiping Lu. My research focuses on domain transferability challenge arising from machine learning (esp. graph-based methods) adoption in real-world drug discovery. Previously, I worked at Apple Siri team as a data engineer, developing large-scale machine learned system. I am contributing to the development of open source PyKale Library and Sheffield AI Turing Network.
research_interest_summary: Deep Representation Learning, Graph Neural Networks and Knowledge Graph in Drug Discovery.

title: Professor
name: Peter Bath
position: Professor of Health Informatics and Data Analytics
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Humanities and Social Sciences
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Privacy and trust, Social data science
short_biography: Peter Bath has been undertaking research applying statistical methods and AI methods to analysing health data for over 25 years. His interests are in identifying predictors of health and well-being in older people, but he is also interested in other groups. He has authored almost 300 publications including 136 articles in refereed journals in print and 115 refereed conference proceedings/abstracts. Recently Peter has been working with colleagues in scHARR to identify predictors of adverse outcomes among people with suspected COVID-19 during the pandemic. Peter has supervised over 30 PhD students to successful completion. Other areas of research interest include health information behaviours and evaluating health information systems.
research_interest_summary: Peter is currently working on the Pre-Hospital PRIEST study, which is developing tools to predict adverse outcomes among people with suspected COVID-19. This has involved the use of statistical methods and AI methods to develop better predictive models. Peter is also examining outcomes among older people through secondary analyses of the English Longitudinal Study of Ageing (ELSA). Other work has involved examining the utility of patient-level data for population health management for the former Rotherham Clinical Commissioning Group (RCCG). Peter is the Training and Capacity Building lead for the HDR-UK Northern Care Homes Partnership.

title: Dr
name: Prasun Chandra Tripathi
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: Prasun Chandra Tripathi received B.Tech. degree from Uttar Pradesh Technical University, Lucknow, and M.Tech. degree from University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad. He did Ph.D. degree from Indian Institute of Technology (ISM), Dhanbad, India. Currently, he is working as a Postdoc Research Associate with Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield.
research_interest_summary: My area of interests lies in medical image analysis, deep learning, and image processing.

title: Mr
name: Rea Nkhumise
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer vision, Information theory, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Multi-agent reasoning, Robotics
short_biography: I'm a robotics engineer with entrepreneurial experience, and have affinity for tackling complex problems with practical application to the general masses - hence I founded a startup company in Robotics & Software. I appreciate the interdisciplinary and system thinking approaches in applying robotics research to mitigate commonly faced societal problems.
research_interest_summary: My work is about Robotic Reinforcement Learning which aims to enable industrial robotic manipulators reach complete autonomy, through self-learning of new tasks and adapting to perturbations fast and flexibly.

title: Professor
name: Richard Clayton
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Parallel computing, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: My undergraduate degree was in Applied Physics, followed by a PhD in Medical Physics based at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle upon Tyne. I continued in research funded by British Heart Foundation fellowships, before moving to Sheffield Computer Science in 2003.
research_interest_summary: My research interests range from physiological signal processing through to multiscale modelling of the heart. More recently I have focussed on statistical machine learning methods for uncertainty quantification and model calibration.

title: Dr
name: Robert Turner
research_interest_terms: Machine learning
short_biography: Bob is a senior research software engineer who started his career in software and databases after completing a degree in Applied Physics at the University of Durham. After four years in the private sector, he did a PhD in Biophysics at the University of Leeds, before working as a postdoc researcher at the University of Sheffield in several departments, including Physics and Astronomy, Molecular Biology and Biotechnology Mechanical Engineering and the Dental School, reflecting an unusually broad range of research interests spanning microscopy, microbiology, engineering and healthcare.
research_interest_summary:
Bob’s role includes contributing to the management of the RSE team, under Paul Richmond’s leadership. His work includes:

- Advising and helping researchers to implement good software engineering practises (e.g. testing, version control, documentation, reproducible execution, packaging, licensing)
- Writing research software (e.g. in Python, MATLAB, R)
- Training
- Establishing new externally-funded collaborations
- Advocating and acting to improve the standards of research software (e.g. running or delivering talks, communication via social media, engagement with university committees)

title: Mr
name: Shunbao Li
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering
research_interest_terms: Knowledge representation, Machine learning

title: Dr
name: Shuo Zhou
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering
research_interest_terms: Machine learning
short_biography:
I am an academic fellow in machine learning at the Machine Learning Research Group, Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield.

My current research focuses on developing interpretable machine learning methods and tools for medical image analysis. I am a co-creator and core developer of open-source library PyKale, which provides a range of accessible multi-modal and transfer learning algorithms.

I serve as a reviewer of IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems and IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems. I also served as a PC member of IJCAI 2022. I am an awardee of Post-Doctoral Enrichment Awards (PDEA) 2022, offered by the Alan Turing Institute.
research_interest_summary: Interpretable Machine Learning, Medical Image Analysis

title: Dr
name: Simone Croft
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, Security and Business and Public Policy, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Visualisation
short_biography: Project Manager for Data Connect, a new university wide service to improve researcher access to health and social care data.
research_interest_summary: Health and social care research

title: Mr
name: Sina Tabakhi
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Information retrieval, Information theory, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: I am a Ph.D. student in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Sheffield, working in the Machine Learning Research Group under the supervision of Dr. Haiping Lu. Before joining UoS, I had worked in the industry as a software engineer for five years, where I was in charge of developing software, bug fixing, and data visualization. I graduated with a Master’s degree as the first honor student in Computer Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, from the University of Kurdistan, supervised by Dr. Parham Moradi.
research_interest_summary: My research aims to reduce the dimensionality of big data through feature selection. Recently, I have been working on machine learning techniques to integrate multi-omics data that help design an accurate life-threatening disease diagnostic system.

title: Dr
name: Tom Stafford
position: Senior Lecturer in Psychology & Cognitive Science
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Multi-agent reasoning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Privacy and trust, Social data science, Visualisation
short_biography: I am also Research Practice Lead, a University-level role with responsibility for encouraging researcher engagement with better practice
research_interest_summary: I am interested in the psychology of learning, decision making and reasoning, and how these may be studied using data intensive methods  and methods from computer science

title: Dr
name: Venet Osmani
position: Senior Lecturer in Data Science for Health
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Data structures and algorithms, Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Multi-agent reasoning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: Before joining the University of Sheffield, I was a tenured Senior Researcher in Digital Health Centre at Fondazione Bruno Kessler research institute, Italy where I led a group of researchers and students in tackling challenges in medicine using machine learning methods. I was also a lecturer in the department of Psychology and Cognitive Science at University of Trento, Italy.
research_interest_summary:
My research interests are in developing machine learning methods, to address some of the fundamental questions in medicine. These include:

    predictive modelling
    explainable AI
    generative adversarial approaches (GAN)
    causal inference
    health inequality and bias

My work focuses on analysis of large-scale, longitudinal health records, including:

    biomarkers
    imaging
    multi-omics
    routine health care data

The main aims are to optimise treatment strategies, improve patient care, and provide novel insights to health institutions.

title: Mr
name: xulong wang
research_interest_terms: Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling
